case_name: The Appellant v. Union of India and State of Jammu and Kashmir

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 37 of 1955 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 37 of 1955. Appeal from the judgment and order dated December 7, 1954,

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated December 7, 1954 of Jammu and Kashmir High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated December 7, 1954, of the Jammu and Kashmir High Court in Criminal Misc. No. 76 of 2011.

facts.text: Appellant was aged 45 years 262 days on August 12, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: He was aged 45 years 262 days on August 12, 1954. He was holding a regular companymission in the Jammu and Kashmir State Forces,

facts.text: Appellant held regular commission in Jammu and Kashmir State Forces, amalgamated with Union Defence Forces effective September 1, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: He was holding a regular companymission in the Jammu and Kashmir State Forces, which were amalgamated with the Defence Forces of the Union with effect from September 1, 1949.

facts.text: Appellant held substantive rank of Lieutenant Colonel in amalgamated forces.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant holding the substantive rank of Lieut. Col. in the amalgamated forces had the right to companytinue in service until he attained the age of 53 years,

facts.text: Appellant had right to continue in service until age 53 on November 20, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant holding the substantive rank of Lieut. Col. in the amalgamated forces had the right to companytinue in service until he attained the age of 53 years, which event will happen on November 20, 1961.

facts.text: Government of India issued letter dated July 31, 1954 retiring appellant effective August 12, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of India issued a letter dated July 31, 1954, retiring the appellant from the service with effect from August 12, 1954, This decision of the Government of India is number based on any allegations or charge of inefficiency,

facts.text: Retirement not based on any allegations of inefficiency, indiscipline or irregularity.

anchor.surface_text: This decision of the Government of India is number based on any allegations or charge of inefficiency, indiscipline or any other irregularity on the part of the appellant.

facts.text: Petition filed under Article 32(2A) against Union of India (Secretary, Ministry of Defence) and State of Jammu and Kashmir (Chief Secretary).

anchor.surface_text: This appeal on a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court of Judicature, Jammu and Kashmir, is directed against the judgment and order dated December 7, 1954, in an application under Art. 32 2A  of the Constitution for issue of. a writ, directions or. order against the Union of India, through the Secretary, Ministry of Defence,, New Delhi, a, the first respondent and the State of Jammu and Kashmir through the Chief Secretary,, Jammu and Kashmir State, as the second respondent.

facts.text: Respondents opposed petition on preliminary ground that Jammu and Kashmir High Court lacked jurisdiction over first respondent (Union of India) as outside territorial limits.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was opposed on behalf of the respondents aforesaid on a number of preliminary grounds of which it is only necessary to mention the first, namely, that the authority against whom the writ is sought, that is to say, respondent No. 1, being outside the territorial limits of the jurisdiction of the Jammu and Kashmir High Court, the same was number maintainable.

facts.text: Jammu and Kashmir High Court Division Bench (Janki Nath Wazir CJ and M. Shahmiri J) upheld preliminary objection by judgment dated December 7, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: This preliminary objection was heard by a Division Bench,  Janki Nath Wazir, C. J. and M. Shahmiri, J.  Jammu and Kashmir High Court. By its judgment. dated December 7, 1954, the High Court upheld the preliminary objection.

facts.text: High Court dismissed petition but granted certificate under Article 132.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court had refused to entertain the appellants petition, on merits. It has been argued on behalf of the appellant, in the first instance, that the previous decisions of this Court were distinguishable on the ground that they did number, in terms, companysider the question whether the Government of India wag amenable to the jurisdiction of the High Court under Art. 226 or of the Jammu and Kashmir High Court under Art. 32 2A  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Matter first heard by Bench of five judges, then referred to larger Bench due to challenge to prior Supreme Court decisions.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was first heard by a Bench of five judges. in the companyrse of hearing it became clear to us that the appellant number only sought to distinguish  1  1953 S.C.R. 1144.  2  1954 S.C.R. 738. the two decisions aforesaid of this Court, but questioned the companyrectness of those decisions. Hence this larger Bench was companystituted

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered December 5, 1960 by Sinha CJ (for himself, Kapur, Gajendragadkar, Wanchoo, Shah JJ).

anchor.surface_text: Sardar Bahadur, for the intervener. 1960. December 5. The Judgment of Sinha, C. J., Kapur, Gajendragadkar, Wanchoo and Shah, JJ., was delivered by Sinha, C. J. Subba Rao, J. and Das Gupta, J. delivered separate judgments.

facts.text: Subba Rao J and Das Gupta J delivered separate judgments.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of Sinha, C. J., Kapur, Gajendragadkar, Wanchoo and Shah, JJ., was delivered by Sinha, C. J. Subba Rao, J. and Das Gupta, J. delivered separate judgments. SINHA, C. J.-This appeal on a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court of Judicature,

facts.text: High Court relied on Supreme Court decisions in Election Commission v. Saka Venkata Subba Rao (1953 SCR 1144) and K.S. Rashid v. Income-tax Investigation Commission (1954 SCR 738).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, relying upon the decisions of this Court in Election Commission, India v. Saka Venkata Subba Rao  1  and K. S. Rashid and Son v. The Income-tax Investigation Commission etc.  2 , held that it had numberjurisdiction to issue a writ against the first respondent

facts.text: Appeal dismissed by majority, with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter the appeal fails and is hereby dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Subba Rao J dissented, would allow appeal and direct High Court to dispose on merits.

anchor.surface_text: In the result,, I allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court and direct it to dispose of the matter in accordance with law. The appellant will have his companyts.

facts.text: Das Gupta J agreed with Sinha CJ that appeal should be dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: I agree with the companyclusions reached by the Chief Justice that the appeal should be dismissed.

issues.text: Whether the word 'authority' in Art. 226 includes 'Government'.

anchor.surface_text: The first argument is that the word authority used in Art. 226 cannot and does not include Government. We are not impressed by this argument. In interpreting the word authority we must have regard to the clause immediately following it.

issues.text: Whether the Government of India as such can be said to have a location in a particular place, viz., New Delhi, irrespective of the fact that its authority extends over all the States and its officers function throughout India.

anchor.surface_text: The two main questions which arise, therefore, are  i  whether the Government of India as such can be said to have a location in a particular place, viz., New Delhi, irrespective of the fact that its authority extends over all the States and its officers function throughout India, and

holdings.text: The exercise of power under Article 226 is subject to a two-fold limitation: (1) the power is to be exercised throughout the territories in relation to which it exercises jurisdiction; (2) the person or authority must be within those territories.

anchor.surface_text: the exercise of the power conferred by that Article was subject to a two-fold limitation, namely, (1) that the power is to be exercised throughout the territories in relation to which it exercises jurisdiction and (2) that the person or authority to whom the High Court is empowered to issue the writs must be within those territories.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reaffirms prior Supreme Court decisions in Election Commission and Rashid cases applying plain language of Article 226.

holdings.text: The word 'authority' in Article 226 includes 'Government' in appropriate cases.

anchor.surface_text: The first argument is that the word authority used in Art. 226 cannot and does not include Government. We are not impressed by this argument. In interpreting the word authority we must have regard to the clause immediately following it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain and reasonable construction of clause 'including in appropriate cases any Government' modifies 'authority'.

holdings.text: The Government of India is located at New Delhi.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Common knowledge of seat of Government; distinguishes functioning from location; rejects all-pervasive presence argument.

holdings.text: There is no scope for introducing the concept of cause of action as the basis of jurisdiction under Article 226.

holdings.text: The appeal is dismissed as Jammu and Kashmir High Court lacked jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter the appeal fails and is hereby dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of two-fold limitation to facts; confirms High Court order.

holdings.text: Previous Supreme Court decisions in Election Commission v. Saka Venkata Subba Rao and K.S. Rashid v. Income-tax Investigation Commission are correct and applicable.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was first heard by a Bench of five judges. in the course of hearing it became clear to us that the appellant not only sought to distinguish 1 1953 S.C.R. 1144. 2 1954 S.C.R. 738. the two decisions aforesaid of this Court, but questioned the correctness of those decisions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reconsideration confirms views; no departure without compelling reasons.

holdings.text: Article 32(2A) enables J&K High Court to issue writs against Union Government as it has functional existence throughout India (dissent).

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether the appellant, who is a citizen of India and is residing in the State of Kashmir, can enforce his fundamental right under Art 32 2A of the Constitution by filing an appropriate writ petition in the High Court of Jammu Kashmir,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive construction; Union has no fixed situs, present everywhere; cause of action within territory suffices.

holdings.text: Union Government is within territories of every State for writ jurisdiction under Article 226/32(2A) (dissent).

anchor.surface_text: Article 73 says that subject to the provisions of the Constitution, the executive power of the Union shall extend to the matters with respect to which Parliament has power to make laws and to the exercise of such rights, authority and jurisdiction

holdings.reasoning_summary: Executive power extends throughout; no fixed legal abode; analogies to suits under Art. 300.

anchor.surface_text: the exercise of the power conferred by that Article was subject to a two-fold limitation, namely, (1) that the power is to be exercised throughout the territories in relation to which it exercises jurisdiction and (2) that the person or authority to whom the High Court is empowered to issue the writs must be within those territories.
In this view of the matter the appeal fails and is hereby dismissed with costs.

edges.explanation: Holding 'authority' includes 'Government' addresses issue whether word 'authority' includes Government

anchor.surface_text: The first argument is that the word authority used in Art. 226 cannot and does not include Government. We are not impressed by this argument. In interpreting the word authority we must have regard to the clause immediately following it.
In this view of the matter the appeal fails and is hereby dismissed with costs.

edges.explanation: Holding Govt located New Delhi (outside J&K) supports no jurisdiction holding

anchor.surface_text: The two main questions which arise, therefore, are (i) whether the Government of India as such can be said to have a location in a particular place, viz., New Delhi, irrespective of the fact that its authority extends over all the States and its officers function throughout India,
In this view of the matter the appeal fails and is hereby dismissed with costs.
